text: We run a very different kind of business. We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. They're focused on growth. So typically, when you have a lot of people, you think you can do more things at once, and you probably can. You do more things at once, and have different offerings to different people, and different tiers, and salespeople, and all the things that build up an organization.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Lenny asks Jason how 37signals can have similar customer numbers to much larger competitors like Asana (1600 employees) and Slack (2500 employees) while maintaining only 75 employees and high profitability. Jason explains that their business philosophy fundamentally differs from their competitors - they prioritize operational efficiency over rapid growth, which allows them to serve customers effectively with a much smaller team.
text_ko: 우리는 좀 다른 방식의 사업을 해요. 저희는 효율성(efficiency)에 초점을 맞추고 있고, 성장(growth)에만 집중하진 않아요. 반대로 그쪽은 성장에 집중하죠. 보통 사람 수가 많아지면 한꺼번에 더 많은 일을 할 수 있다고 생각하게 되고, 아마 어느 정도는 그럴 수 있어요. 동시에 여러 일을 하고, 고객마다 다른 상품(offering)을 내놓거나 티어(tier)를 나누고, 영업 담당자(salespeople)를 두는 등 조직을 키우는 데 필요한 여러 요소들이 생겨나요.
text_zh: 我们的生意模式跟别人很不一样。我们主要抓效率，不像他们那样一心想着做大做强。一般来说，人多了就觉得能同时搞很多项目，确实也能做到。同时推进各种业务，针对不同客户搞不同的产品和服务层级，配销售团队，把组织架构搭得很复杂。
text_es: Nosotros manejamos un negocio muy diferente. Nos enfocamos en la eficiencia, no en el crecimiento. Ellos se enfocan en el crecimiento. Entonces típicamente, cuando tienes mucha gente, crees que puedes hacer más cosas a la vez, y probablemente sí puedas. Haces más cosas al mismo tiempo, tienes diferentes ofertas para diferentes personas, diferentes niveles, vendedores, y todas esas cosas que van armando una organización.
key_sentence: We focus on efficiency, not on building up an organization with different tiers.

text: What that allows us to do is to just build one product, do a really nice job, keep it tight, and simple, and clear, and not have the complexity that comes with trying to service and satisfy so many different kinds of companies at different price levels with different price points and different expectations.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Jason continues explaining why 37signals can operate with far fewer employees than competitors. He describes their pricing strategy where no customer can pay more than $299 regardless of company size, which eliminates the need for complex enterprise sales processes, multiple product tiers, and extensive support infrastructure that typically require large teams.
text_ko: 그렇게 하면 저희는 한 가지 제품(product)만 만들어서 정말 잘 다듬고, 깔끔하고 단순하며 명확하게 유지할 수 있어요. 여러 가격대(price levels)나 가격 포인트(price points), 기대치가 다른 다양한 회사들을 만족시키려다 보면 생기는 복잡함이 없거든요.
text_zh: 这样我们就能专心做好一个产品，把它做得特别棒，保持精简、简单、清晰，不用搞得那么复杂——不用去服务和满足各种不同类型的公司，不同的价位，不同的价格点，不同的期望值。
text_es: Lo que eso nos permite hacer es enfocarnos en construir un solo producto, hacerlo realmente bien, mantenerlo simple y claro, sin toda esa complejidad que viene cuando tratas de atender y satisfacer a tantos tipos diferentes de empresas con distintos niveles de precios, diferentes price points y expectativas completamente distintas.
key_sentence: We keep it tight, avoiding complexity in service and satisfy different companies.

text: If you think about all of the space between a small business and a massive, huge unicorn-y business, there's so much room there that you could normally find your own way, and slide into a slot or a place that makes sense for you. But if you're venture-backed, you just don't even have the opportunity. You blow right past those, or they want you to blow right past those.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Lenny asks Jason about when raising venture capital makes sense versus bootstrapping. Jason argues that venture funding severely limits a company's options because investors require massive growth and unicorn-level outcomes. He explains that there are many profitable business models between small businesses and billion-dollar companies, but venture-backed companies must skip over these sustainable options.
text_ko: 작은 사업과 엄청 큰 유니콘 같은 기업(unicorn) 사이를 생각해보면, 그 사이에는 스스로 길을 찾고 자신에게 맞는 틈새나 자리를 찾아 들어갈 수 있을 만큼 여지가 정말 많아요. 그런데 벤처 투자를 받은(venture-backed) 회사라면 그런 기회조차 없어요. 그 사이를 그냥 지나쳐 버리게 되거나, 투자자들이 그렇게 하길 바라기도 해요.
text_zh: 你想想，从小企业到那种超大规模的独角兽企业之间，其实有很大的发展空间，正常情况下你完全可以找到适合自己的位置，慢慢发展到一个合适的规模。但是如果你拿了风投的钱，就根本没有这个机会了。你要么直接跳过这些阶段，要么投资人就是希望你跳过这些阶段。
text_es: Si te pones a pensar en todo el espacio que hay entre un negocio pequeño y una empresa gigantesca tipo unicornio (unicorn), hay muchísimo lugar ahí donde normalmente podrías encontrar tu propio camino y meterte en un nicho o posición que te funcione. Pero si tienes capital de riesgo (venture capital), simplemente no tienes ni la oportunidad. Te saltas todas esas opciones de una, o ellos quieren que te las saltes.
key_sentence: Venture-backed companies blow right past opportunities in the unicorn-y business space.

text: The reason I think it's great for entrepreneurs to start bootstrapping is because they just have more practice making money, and they get better, and better, and better at the fundamental skill you need to have ultimately to run a successful business, which is to make money.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Jason explains why he advocates for bootstrapping over raising venture capital. He argues that bootstrapped entrepreneurs develop crucial money-making skills through constant practice, while venture-funded companies often become skilled at spending money rather than generating profit. This fundamental difference in experience affects a company's ability to eventually become profitable when investor funding becomes scarce.
text_ko: 제가 창업자들이 부트스트래핑(bootstrapping)으로 시작하는 걸 좋다고 생각하는 이유는, 실제로 수익을 내보는 연습을 더 많이 하게 되고 그 과정에서 수익 창출 능력이 계속해서 더 좋아지기 때문이에요. 결국 성공적인 사업을 운영하려면 가장 근본적인 기술이 수익을 창출하는 능력인데, 부트스트래핑을 통해 그 기술을 반복해서 단련할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得创业者一开始自力更生(bootstrapping)特别好，因为这样他们赚钱的实战经验更多，会越来越熟练，越来越擅长这个最核心的技能——毕竟要想把生意做成功，说到底还是得会赚钱。
text_es: La razón por la que creo que es genial que los emprendedores empiecen haciendo bootstrapping es porque así practican más el arte de generar dinero, y van mejorando cada vez más en la habilidad fundamental que necesitas para manejar un negocio exitoso, que es precisamente eso: hacer dinero.
key_sentence: Bootstrapping gives entrepreneurs practice making money, a fundamental skill for success.

text: Starting a business is actually way easier than staying in business. Now, none of it's easy, so I want to be supportive of people who are starting businesses. But they should know that that's actually not the hard part. Literally tomorrow, I can start a new business. You can come up with a name, and you can make a thing, and you can put in the app store, and you can sell it for two bucks, and you've got a business going.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Jason introduces his concept of 'stay ups' versus 'startups' when discussing business sustainability. He argues that while the startup world celebrates launching new businesses, the real challenge lies in maintaining a business over time through competition, employee management, and market changes. This perspective reflects his focus on long-term business sustainability rather than initial launch success.
text_ko: 사업을 시작하는 건 사실 사업을 유지하는 것보다 훨씬 쉬워요. 근데 그렇다고 쉬운 게 하나도 없는 건 맞아서, 창업하는 사람들을 응원하고 싶어요. 다만 그들이 알아야 할 건, 그게 진짜 어려운 부분은 아니라는 거예요. 말 그대로 내일 당장이라도 새 사업을 시작할 수 있어요. 이름 짓고, 뭔가 하나 만들어서 앱스토어(App Store)에 올리고 2달러에 팔면 그걸로 사업이 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 创业其实比守业要容易得多。当然，这些都不简单，我也很支持那些正在创业的人。但他们得知道，创业真的不是最难的那一步。说白了，明天我就能开个新公司。你想个名字，做个产品，放到应用商店(app store)里，卖个两美金，生意就算开张了。
text_es: Montar un negocio en realidad es mucho más fácil que mantenerse en el mercado. Ahora, que nada de esto es fácil, ¿eh? Quiero apoyar a la gente que está empezando negocios. Pero tienen que saber que esa parte no es la más difícil. Literalmente mañana puedo arrancar un negocio nuevo. Te inventas un nombre, haces algo, lo subes a la tienda de aplicaciones, lo vendes por dos dólares, y ya tienes un negocio funcionando.
key_sentence: Staying in business is harder than starting a business; both are not easy.

text: I almost would be embarrassed by what someone would come in and look at, and go, 'Oh my God, you guys are missing so many opportunities here.' I'd be like, 'Yeah, I know. I know we are, but I'm totally fine with it.' But, there'd be this moment of judgment and reckoning with, 'Do you realize how much you're leaving on the table?'
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Lenny asks Jason what he thinks would happen if someone else ran 37signals. Jason reflects on how a different leader would likely focus on growth opportunities that he consciously ignores, such as multiple pricing tiers, specialized product versions, and aggressive marketing spend. He acknowledges these missed opportunities but expresses contentment with their current approach of intentional simplicity.
text_ko: 누군가 들어와서 보고 “세상에, 여기서 얼마나 많은 기회를 놓치고 있네요” 라고 하면 거의 민망해요. 저는 “네, 알아요. 우리가 그렇게 하고 있는 거, 저도 알아요. 근데 전 괜찮아요” 라고 말할 것 같아요. 그런데 그런 순간에는 “자신들이 얼마나 많은 걸 그냥 놓아두고 있는지 아세요?” 라는 판단의 순간과 마주하게 되죠.
text_zh: 要是有人进来看了我们的情况，然后说"天哪，你们错过了这么多机会"，我都觉得有点不好意思。我会说"对，我知道，我们确实错过了不少，但我完全能接受。" 不过那一刻还是会有点被人指指点点的感觉，人家会问"你们知道自己白白浪费了多少机会吗？"
text_es: Casi me daría pena que alguien viniera, echara un vistazo y dijera: "¡Dios mío, se están perdiendo un montón de oportunidades aquí!" Y yo estaría como: "Sí, ya lo sé. Sé que es así, pero estoy totalmente tranquilo con eso." Pero habría ese momento de juicio y ajuste de cuentas con: "¿Te das cuenta de todo el dinero que estás dejando sobre la mesa?"
key_sentence: There's a moment of judgment and reckoning about leaving opportunities on the table.

text: Work expands to fill the time available. So for us it's about appetite. So the idea of appetites, maxing things out at six weeks, two people max, and then there's a lot of other details, and I could go on for an hour about Shape Up, people can read about it.
speaker: Jason Fried
context: Jason explains 37signals' Shape Up development methodology to Lenny. He describes how they use 'appetites' instead of estimates - setting a fixed time budget (maximum six weeks) and team size (two people) for any feature, rather than estimating how long work will take. This approach prevents projects from extending indefinitely and forces teams to find the simplest effective solution within constraints.
vocabulary_highlights: work expands to fill the time available
text_ko: 일은 주어진 시간만큼 늘어나기 마련이에요. 그래서 우리에게는 욕구가 중요해요. 그래서 최대 6주 동안 두 명이서 최대한 밀어붙이는 아이디어가 필요하고, 그 외에도 많은 세부사항이 있어요. 'Shape Up'에 대해 한 시간 동안 이야기할 수 있지만, 사람들은 그걸 읽어보면 될 것 같아요.
text_zh: 工作量总是会填满你给它的时间。所以对我们来说关键是要控制胃口。就是这个胃口的概念，最多六周，最多两个人，把事情控制在这个范围内，还有很多其他细节，我可以讲一个小时关于Shape Up这套方法，大家可以去了解一下。
text_es: El trabajo siempre se expande para ocupar todo el tiempo que tienes disponible. Entonces para nosotros se trata del apetito. O sea, la idea de los apetitos, limitando todo a máximo seis semanas, máximo dos personas, y después hay un montón de otros detalles. Me podría pasar una hora hablando de Shape Up, pero la gente puede leer sobre eso.
key_sentence: Work expands to fill the time available, maxing things out at six weeks.
